<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 119, 380, 146]]<|/det|> Cambridge IGCSE™ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 185]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 220, 165, 236]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 213, 424, 260]]<|/det|>
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[891, 279, 905, 294]]<|/det|> 0606/12 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[731, 302, 905, 317]]<|/det|> February/March 2025 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[840, 326, 905, 341]]<|/det|> 2 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 396, 372]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 361, 399]]<|/det|> No additional materials are needed. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 432]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 433, 291, 450]]<|/det|> - Answer all questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 449, 761, 466]]<|/det|> - Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 464, 808, 481]]<|/det|> - Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 480, 565, 497]]<|/det|> - Write your answer to each question in the space provided. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 497, 482, 512]]<|/det|> - Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 511, 361, 528]]<|/det|> - Do not write on any bar codes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 526, 452, 544]]<|/det|> - Calculators must not be used in this paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 542, 468, 559]]<|/det|> - You must show all necessary working clearly. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 214, 602]]<|/det|> INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 603, 388, 620]]<|/det|> - The total mark for this paper is 80. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 618, 730, 636]]<|/det|> - The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 105, 477, 122]]<|/det|>
Equation of a circle with centre \((a, b)\) and radius \(r\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[603, 101, 790, 124]]<|/det|>
\[
(x-a)^{2}+(y-b)^{2}=r^{2}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 156, 537, 172]]<|/det|>
Curved surface area, \(A\), of cone of radius \(r\), sloping edge \(l\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[603, 154, 678, 172]]<|/det|>
\[
A=\pi r l
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 202, 373, 219]]<|/det|>
Surface area, \(A\), of sphere of radius \(r\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[603, 199, 686, 218]]<|/det|>
\[
A=4 \pi r^{2}
\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[603, 244, 680, 273]]<|/det|>
\[
V=\frac{1}{3} A h
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 248, 496, 266]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of pyramid or cone, base area \(A\), height \(h\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[603, 290, 686, 319]]<|/det|>
\[
V=\frac{4}{3} \pi r^{3}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 297, 336, 315]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of sphere of radius \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 345, 234, 362]]<|/det|>
Quadratic equation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 344, 656, 362]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(a x^{2}+b x+c=0\),

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 365, 554, 399]]<|/det|>
\[
x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^{2}-4 a c}}{2 a}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 441, 225, 457]]<|/det|>
Binomial theorem

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 429, 907, 519]]<|/det|>
\[
(a+b)^{n}=a^{n}+\binom{n}{1} a^{n-1} b+\binom{n}{2} a^{n-2} b^{2}+\ldots+\binom{n}{r} a^{n-r} b^{r}+\ldots+b^{n},
\quad \text { where } n \text { is a positive integer and } \binom{n}{r}=\frac{n !}{(n-r) ! r !}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 548, 217, 563]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 544, 678, 588]]<|/det|>
\[
\begin{aligned}
& u_{n}=a+(n-1) d \\
& S_{n}=\frac{1}{2} n(a+l)=\frac{1}{2} n\{2 a+(n-1) d\}
\end{aligned}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 622, 216, 637]]<|/det|>
Geometric series

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 620, 567, 706]]<|/det|>
\[
\begin{aligned}
& u_{n}=a r^{n-1} \\
& S_{n}=\frac{a(1-r^{n})}{1-r} \quad(r \neq 1) \\
& S_{\infty}=\frac{a}{1-r} \quad(|r|<1)
\end{aligned}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 734, 157, 749]]<|/det|>
Identities

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 729, 555, 782]]<|/det|>
\[
\begin{aligned}
& \sin ^{2} A+\cos ^{2} A=1 \\
& \sec ^{2} A=1+\tan ^{2} A \\
& \operatorname{cosec}^{2} A=1+\cot ^{2} A
\end{aligned}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 823, 240, 840]]<|/det|>
Formulas for \(\Delta A B C\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 816, 583, 896]]<|/det|>
\[
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{a}{\sin A}=\frac{b}{\sin B}=\frac{c}{\sin C} \\
& a^{2}=b^{2}+c^{2}-2 b c \cos A \\
& \Delta=\frac{1}{2} a b \sin C
\end{aligned}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 103, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
1 (a) On the axes, sketch the graphs of \(y=4|x-1|\) and \(y=|3 x+2|\), stating the intercepts with the axes.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[152, 150, 832, 497]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 516, 477, 535]]<|/det|>
(b) Solve the inequality \(4|x-1| \leqslant|3 x+2|\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 97, 88]]<|/det|>
2

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 95, 877, 312]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 336, 684, 352]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve \(y=a \cos b x+c\) for \(-180^{\circ} \leqslant x \leqslant 180^{\circ}\). It is given that \(a, b\) and \(c\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 382, 347, 397]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(a, b\) and \(c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 536, 405, 553]]<|/det|>
3 The point \(A\) has coordinates ( \(-3,6\) ). The point \(B\) has coordinates \((7,-8)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 583, 736, 599]]<|/det|>
Given that the line \(A B\) is the diameter of a circle, find the equation of the circle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 811, 96]]<|/det|>
4 The polynomial p is given by \(\mathrm{p}(x)=a^{2} x^{3}+2 a x^{2}+a x+2\) ，where \(a\) is a positive integer． It is given that \(2 x+1\) is a factor of \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 125, 311, 142]]<|/det|>
（a）Find the value of \(a\) ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 495, 327, 512]]<|/det|>
（b）Hence factorise \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 695, 664, 713]]<|/det|>
（c）Hence show that the equation \(\mathrm{p}(x)=0\) has only one real root．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 766, 101]]<|/det|>
5 (a) Write \(2 x^{2}-2 x+3\) in the form \(a(x+b)^{2}+c\), where \(a, b\) and \(c\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 263, 532, 284]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\mathrm{f}(x)=2 x^{2}-2 x+3\), for \(x \leqslant p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 297, 637, 315]]<|/det|>
(b) Write down the greatest value of \(p\) for which f has an inverse.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 419, 533, 438]]<|/det|>
(c) Using this value of \(p\), write down the range of f .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 556, 540, 579]]<|/det|>
(d) Using this value of \(p\), find an expression for \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 523, 107]]<|/det|>
6 It is given that \(\tan \theta=\frac{\sqrt{5}}{5}\) and \(180^{\circ}<\theta<360^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 115, 344, 134]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the value of \(\cos \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 300, 340, 317]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the value of \(\sin \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 454, 407, 473]]<|/det|>
(c) Find the value of \(\sec \theta+\cot \theta\). Give your answer in the form \(\frac{a+b \sqrt{c}}{\sqrt{5}}\), where \(a, b\) and \(c\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
7

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 95, 903, 417]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 431, 918, 460]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows part of the curve \(y=\frac{5}{x+1}+2\) and part of the line \(y=2 x+1\) intersecting at

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 454, 211, 469]]<|/det|>
the point \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 484, 361, 501]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the coordinates of \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 74, 474, 91]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the exact area of the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 487, 91]]<|/det|>
8 The first term of a geometric progression is 10 . This geometric progression has a positive common ratio \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 121, 535, 138]]<|/det|>
The first term of an arithmetic progression is also 10. This arithmetic progression has a negative common difference \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 166, 843, 183]]<|/det|>
The second term of the geometric progression is the same as the fourth term of the arithmetic progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 197, 915, 215]]<|/det|>
The third term of the geometric progression is the same as the sixth term of the arithmetic progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 228, 366, 245]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the values of \(r\) and \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 722, 680, 739]]<|/det|>
(b) Determine whether the geometric progression has a sum to infinity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 76, 468, 102]]<|/det|>
10 The point \(P\) lies on the curve \(y=(5 x+2)^{\frac{2}{3}}\) ． The \(x\)－coordinate of \(P\) is 5 ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 115, 693, 132]]<|/det|>
The normal to the curve at \(P\) intersects the line \(x+y=11\) at the point \(Q\) ． The point \(R\) is the reflection of \(Q\) in the tangent to the curve at \(P\) ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 162, 322, 175]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of \(R\) ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 76, 454, 91]]<|/det|>
Continuation of working space for Question 10.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 105, 89]]<|/det|>
11

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 94, 838, 313]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 333, 413, 354]]<|/det|>
In the diagram, \(\overrightarrow{O A}=\mathbf{a}\) and \(\overrightarrow{O B}=\mathbf{b}\). The point \(M\) is the midpoint of \(O B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 371, 402, 392]]<|/det|>
The point \(N\) is such that \(\overrightarrow{O N}=3 \overrightarrow{N A}\). The lines \(B N\) and \(A M\) intersect at the point \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 410, 391, 428]]<|/det|>
\(\overrightarrow{B X}=\lambda \overrightarrow{B N}\), where \(\lambda\) is a constant. \(\overrightarrow{M X}=\mu \overrightarrow{M A}\), where \(\mu\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 459, 410, 479]]<|/det|>
(a) Find \(\overrightarrow{O X}\) in terms of \(\mathbf{a}, \mathbf{b}\) and \(\lambda\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 76, 411, 97]]<|/det|>
(b) Find \(\overrightarrow{O X}\) in terms of \(\mathbf{a}, \mathbf{b}\) and \(\mu\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 497, 421, 516]]<|/det|>
(c) Hence find the values of \(\lambda\) and \(\mu\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 76, 335, 95]]<|/det|>
12 It is given that \(y=x \mathrm{e}^{3 x+2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 99, 231, 131]]<|/det|>
(a) Find \(\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{~d} x}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 347, 352, 380]]<|/det|>
(b) Hence find \(\int x \mathrm{e}^{3 x+2} \mathrm{~d} x\).
